qas.question: In what year was Nebraska's death penalty statute ruled unconstitutional by a state court?
What state's court ruled capital punishment unconstitutional in 1984?
In what case did the Kansas Supreme Court rule that the death penalty is unconstitutional in Kansas?
What method of execution did the Nebraska Supreme Court rule unconstitutional?
After electrocution was outlawed, how were Nebraska death row inmates executed?
In what year was Kansas' death penalty statute ruled unconstitutional by a state court?
What state's court ruled capital punishment unconstitutional in 1884?
In what case did the Arkansas Supreme Court rule that the death penalty is unconstitutional in Arkansas?
What method of execution did the Nebraska Supreme Court rule constitutional?

context: Four states in the modern era, Nebraska in <a0_0><b5_0>2008<b5_0/><a0_0/>, New York and Kansas in 2004, and <a1_0>Massachusetts<a1_0/> in 1984, had their statutes ruled unconstitutional by state courts. The death rows of New York and <b6_0>Massachusetts<b6_0/> were disestablished, and attempts to restore the death penalty were unsuccessful. Kansas successfully appealed <a2_0><b7_0>State v. Kleypas<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the Kansas Supreme Court decision that declared the state's death penalty statute unconstitutional, to the United States Supreme Court. Nebraska's death penalty statute was rendered ineffective on February 8, 2008 when the required method, <a3_0><b8_0>electrocution<b8_0/><a3_0/>, was ruled unconstitutional by the Nebraska Supreme Court. In 2009, Nebraska enacted a bill that changed its method of execution to <a4_0>lethal injection<a4_0/>.
